messages.content: Don't make assumptions about what values to plug into functions. Ask for clarification if a user request is ambiguous.

I don't currently have access to your location information. If you enable location services or provide your current latitude and longitude, I can help identify what city you are in. Would you like to enable location services?

messages.name: set_location_service_status
messages.content: PermissionError: Location service cannot be turned on in low battery mode

I wasn't able to enable location services because your device is currently in low battery mode. Would you like me to turn off low battery mode so I can enable location services and determine your city?
Yeah, please turn off low battery mode.

Low battery mode is now turned off, and I have enabled location services. Could you please provide your current latitude and longitude? This will help me determine what city you are in. If your device can share this information, please allow it or type in the coordinates.
I don't have that info. Can you find it?

I don't have direct access to your device's location data. Usually, your device or browser will provide latitude and longitude if you allow location permissions. You may see a prompt to share your location—please accept it if you want me to look up your city.

If you do not see a prompt or can't access your coordinates, you can check your device's settings or use a map service (like Google Maps) to find your latitude and longitude, then share them here. Once you provide the coordinates, I can identify your city. Let me know how you'd like to proceed!
I'm not seeing any prompt, and I don't have access to my coordinates right now. Can you try another way?

I understand the situation. Unfortunately, I don’t have the ability to directly access your device’s location without your input or a system-level prompt, and there isn’t another way for me to automatically detect your city without latitude and longitude data or other identifying information.

Here are a few alternative suggestions for finding your city:

1. Check Settings or System Info: On most smartphones or computers, your current city is usually listed in your device’s location settings or weather app.
2. Visit WhatIsMyLocation.com or a similar website: These services can usually display your current city and coordinates.
3. Check your Browser: Some web browsers display location info in the lower corner while using map services.
4. Let me know a nearby landmark, postal/zip code, or address: If you can provide any partial info, I can help identify the city.

If you can provide any of the above, I’ll do my best to help you!
